column4:
1.to tested the prediction that mrPFC might be involved in appraising the personality traits of another person to the degree that this person is perceived as similar to oneself. 
2.to examined whether recruiting common processes for thinking about oneself and others might impact on subsequent memory for those judgments.
column5: to examine how acculturation period alters brain activity associated with self-referential cognition.
column6: to test whether acting with a group will reduce spontaneous self-referential processing in the moral domain and, in turn, facilitate competitor harm.
column7: to disentangle the neural correlates of self-referential processing and perspective taking
column8: whether the mPFC would show effects of the self-positivity bias in a paradigm that probed participants’ self-concept without any requirement of explicit self-judgment
column9: to identify the brain regions mediating interactions between self-related processing and emotional processing
column10: to explore whether medial prefrontal cortex could be engaged similarly by both young and elderly adults under appropriate task demands
column11:
1.to explore age differences in the memory encoding network as a function of the social and self-relevant nature of stimuli
2.to assess the degree to which the specificity of the mPFC response to social information was intact with age.
column12: to assess whether this religious belief is associated with neural correlates of self-referential processing distinct from that of non-religious people.
column13: 1.to investigated neural consequences of Buddhist belief and practice on self-referential processing.
column14: use event-related fMRI to examine the extent to which MPFC activity differentiates self from close others.
column15: to explores the functional overlap and dissociability of self-referential and social stimulus processing.
column16: investigating the neural correlates during attribution of gender stereotypes to oneself or to a prototypical female and male actor
column17: to examined the extent to which these different forms of self-reflection are subserved by common mechanisms.
column18: investigate whether self-other comparisons rely on the activity of these self-relevant structures instead of frontoparietal regions
column19: to investigate potential neural substrates of self-referential processing
column20: to directly compare DMN vs. TPN connectivity during self- and other-appraisal in the trait adjective judgment task for different others varying in the degree of their closeness to the self
column21: to examine whether MPFC modulation that distinguishes self-evaluation from evaluation of a non-close other relates to (a) memory effects presumed to reflect deeper encoding and/or (b) socioemotional association (disentangled from previous knowledge)
column22: to examine whether MPFC (1) indexes socioemotional association in relation to repetition suppression, target effects, trait relevance, and MVPA and (2) is parametrically modulated by perceived similarity
column23:
to examine the neural correlates of self-descriptiveness and self-reference effect in
 memory
column24: to examine the neural representations of mentalizing about known others in young and older adults across a continuum of social closeness
column25: to investigate the behavioral and neural activity differences between 1PP and 3PP when Buddhists considered themselves
column26: to gain insight into the mechanisms involved in processing these different aspects of the self and the other
column27: to determine whether medial parietal cortex in this network is essential forepisodic memory retrieval with self-representation
column29:
to invesitage this (context-independent/context-dependent self-representation)
issue by examining the neural correlates of both kinds of self-knowledge
column30: 1) to clarify whether insula activity would be intrinsically involved in self-reflection, and 2) to replicate and expand current understanding of the neural network underlying self-reflection using an fMRI task previously associated with robust activity in midline structures
column31: to examine investigate brain activation associated with self-reflection in individuals with high as compared to individuals with low positive-dimension PP
column32: to examine whether differences between self and others are related to differences in knowledge about character and appearance
column33: to examine the behavioral and neural correlates of parenting self-evaluation
column34: to examine the common and distinct neural bases of direct appraisals of the self, close others, and normative judgments of trait desirability
column35:
1. to compare direct appraisals of the self with a close other and a non-close other to see how activation varies with relationship intimac
2. to examine the common and distinct neural bases of (1) direct appraisals of self, a close other or a non-close other, and (2) reflected appraisals made from the perspective of a close or a non-close other
column36: to examine the influence of mood on self-evaluation
column37: to explore the cerebral correlates of positive self-evaluation and its influence on memory
column38:
1. to identify the neural correlates of self- and social knowledge retrieval in children
2. to directly compare the systems involved in these processes in children and adults
column39: to investigate whether the cognitive processes of agentic self(being an agent who acts to achieve oneʼs own goals) and conceptual self(knowledge of one's traits) overlap
column40: to investigate whether the cognitive processes of agentic self(being an agent who acts to achieve oneʼs own goals) and conceptual self(knowledge of one's traits) overlap
column41: to compared metacognitive evaluation associated with two referentially discrete targets: oneself and a significant other
column42: to confirm the existence of the SRE for both personality traits and social identities
column43: to assess self-referential brain activities, using fMRI
column44: to investigate changes in coupling between areas of the DMN during self-referential processing
column45: to investigate whether evaluating self- and mother-traits in three domains relies on similar or distinct brain regions
column46: to compare BOLD signal changes during self and mother conditions of a self-reference effect (SRE) task
column47: to investigate how emotion and self-referential processing influence directed forgetting
column48: to investigate neural processes when people reflect on oneself and others in relationships
column49: to test the hypothesis that close others such as mother, father and best friend are differentially represented in collectivistic (i.e. Chinese) brains in relation to the self.
column50: to test whether chronic dialectical thinkers would be more likely to utilize the dACC
column51: to investigate the significant role of religion on the functional anatomy of self-representation
column52: to investigate Chinese culture’s influence on the concept of self, in which the self includes mother
column53: to investigate Chinese culture’s influence on the concept of self, in which the self includes mother
column54: to investigate neural mechanism underlying the association between levels of self-esteem and processing of self-relevant information.
column55: to examine whether and how neural activity related to self–evaluation and social feedback can be related to one’s trait self–esteem and whether and how trait self–esteem can be associated with the neural activity related to both task and attitude
column56: to investigate brain activities during the processing of referential information relating to either the self or a distant other
column57: to elucidate the neural mechanisms underlying this self-bias
column58: to investigate neural activity associated with self-referential processing of emotional stimuli
column59: to identify neurological indicators in the processing of personal, relational, and collective self-worth and to investigate whether these neural indicators could reflect individual differences of self-esteem
column60: to investigate Chinese culture’s influence on the concept of self, in which the self includes mother

column25: The trait judgment task included four scans, each containing four blocks. In each block participants completed twelve trials of one specific condition. The order of the blocks were counterbalanced using a Latin Squire design. Each session of every condition lasted for 38 s, including a 2 s instruction and 12 trials. Amongst the task blocks were the null session that lasted for 30 s, in which participants passively viewed the asterisks on the screen. All of the stimuli were presented in their native language. Participants used their left and right index fingers to make judgments by pressing buttons. After trait judgment task, structural scan was obtained.
column33: The task included two runs, with 10 blocks per run. Each block began with a 4.7-s cue instructing participants how to respond to the following trials, followed by five to six trials of 4.7 s each separated by a jittered inter-stimulus-interval (ISI) averaging 277 ms. Blocks were separated by a jittered rest period averaging 4.98 s. A total of 26 trials were conducted in each of 4 conditions: instruction block (self, change) by trial type (developmentally supportive, developmentally unsupportive). Each trial (see Table 1 for stimuli) was seen under each instruction, and traits were mixed within blocks. General code can be found at gitlab.com/dsnlab/svc.
